"What is it about abortion that gives it such political staying power? One obvious answer it is that for opponents it is an issue of life and death. For pro-choice women, it is a question of personal autonomy and bodily integrity."

A few observations...

First, one cannot begin to answer this question without looking at how sex education has been impacted over the last thirty years due to aggressive lobbying by religious and right-wing groups locally to pare curriculum taught in our schools, going from state to state, What young people know about the way their bodies work and how life begins is woefully inadequate, to put it mildly.

Second, what we collectively learn about philosophy and social ethics during the formative years of our lives - those years we spend in school - is woefully inadequate in two important ways:

1. We don't learn how to think critically early enough and in the ways that matter most.

2. We don't learn the things philosophers discovered through the ages early enough and, therefore, don't think deeply about life's existential questions unless we have some need to (can be personal circumstance or taking Philosophy 1 to get rid of a college requirement).

Which leads to our political situation today. The far right is able to make inroads due to a number of factors, including less than adequate public participation at the polls and due to shifts in beliefs that correlate to a targeted decrease in information.

Fascinating point. Though I'm an extensive reader of history, I've never heard of this phenomenon. Well, yes, loss of body, but never to the extent of war time loss, especially during the Civil War. Do any studies exist on this?

An interesting, useful article, but Professor Marshall does not deal with the thesis of Professor Faust's book, which is that the horror felt by Americans in that era over the heavy losses of the war stemmed in part from the fact that so many soldiers killed in battle could never be identified.  Religious people took literally the statement in the Bible that the elect would keep their physical bodies in heaven.  How could this be possible if those bodies were destroyed or lost in war? The anguish generated by this impact of war drove many people, during and after the war, to go to great lengths to try to identify and recover the bodies of their lost loved ones.  It is not presentism to take this situation into account when weighing the effect of the war on the American people, north and south.

The other statistic if the Civil War was the death rate, from wounds we can cure today. Not only were the doctors able to repair an internal wound, even a bone broken from a gunshot had to be amputated, and infection was rampant. Surgical tools were not cleaned, hands were not washed, doctors had no understanding of how infections were carried by them, from patient to patient. You chances of dying from what we would consider minor injuries today, were about 70% as I recall reading. Just a minnie ball in the shoulder could be fatal.

But as was pointed out, disease killed more than combat. Cholera killed the 49rs as they crossed the plains, and once they reached the Rockies it abated, but connecting it to polluted water did not occur until several years later. And it was rampant during the Civil War, when all it really took was to boil the water.

These are interesting findings, and the researchers should provide a link to their study. The consistent homework help finding has causality issues: if your child is getting As you have no need to help them with their homework, but if they are struggling you do. Students who struggle with school work, and thus need parental help, may not score as high on standardized tests as peers who do not need consistent help. Also, how do the authors explain the fact that reading to black children negatively affects their reading ability? This has to be an error in control or something. Verbal input has constantly been shown to correlate with higher reading comprehension ability. Not on a statistical level, just theoretically, what is the pathway that causes verbal input to have negative effects on black children? I would like to read the authors' explanation of this finding -- One that seems incongruent with previous research.

AACNY:

Let's look at your implied logic:

Because technology might (not guaranteed, just MIGHT) be able to save the life of a 20 week preemie who is already born, you suggest that society should force a woman who does not want to carry a pregnancy to term to do so once the 20 week point is reached.

Where is the logical connection of your premise to your conclusion? That a possible medical solution must be applied in all instances, including a situation where the "medical solution" has no relevance? Who said that? Why would that be true?

Please explain why another person's pregnancy is any of your business, especially if you have no connection of any kind (family, friendship, or even simple acquaintance) with that person. Who or what gives you the right to poke your nose into that situation? And what gives you the information as to when 20 weeks has passed?

My thinking is that when you agree to show all of society your private medical information, then, and only then, do you even have the right to ask to see mine or that of anyone else. Don't count on my complying with your request.

Technology has allowed us to not only see the growing fetus but to keep infants born premature alive.  It has moved the infant's viability in people's mind to a much earlier point and explains the widespread opposition to abortions beyond 20 weeks.
